ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The operators of the Baker Commodities facility has an emergency action plan in effect.  The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP document which is maintained at the facility.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

  1.)  To save lives.
  2.)  To minimize and avoid injuries.
  3.)  To protect the environment.
  4.)  To minimize property damage.

Baker Commodities maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Construction of the ammonia refrigeration system at Baker Commodities was completed in December 2001.  The facility is located at 4100 Bandini Boulevard, Vernon, California,  90023.  It is owned by Baker Commodities and is operated by Inland Cold Storage.  The system was constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations including the 1997 Uniform Fire and Mechanical Codes.

The ammonia refrigeration system uses 20,000 pounds of ammonia for storage freezers and dock operations.  The majority of the system is located in the machine room including vessels and compressors.  The condensers are mounted on the roof, and all of the evaporators are located in their respective cold areas.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Baker Commodities ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the Baker Commodities facility operates in accordance with Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation. 

The Baker Commodities facility including the ammonia system was designed and constructed in accordance with the 1997 Uniform Mechanical Code which specifically outlines requiremen

ts for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  These safety features include a water diffusion tank, ammonia sensors in the machine room as well as sensors near the evaporators, and automatic shut down systems.  In addition, the majority of the ammonia is maintained inside the machine room and just outside of the machine room (condensers).  All pressure vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves that are commonly piped to the water diffusion tank.

In addition to the 1997 Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility will operate in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines. 


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Because this is a new ammonia refrigeration system, there have been no accidental ammonia releases at the Baker Commodities facility within the last five years.  In addition, Inland Cold Storage, who will be operating the Baker facility, currently operates three other ammonia refrigerated warehouses and none have had an accidental release of ammonia in the last five years (December 1996 - December 2001).


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Baker Commodities has an emergency action plan in effect at the facility.  The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of this PSM/RMP document.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

  1.)  To save lives.
  2.)  To minimize and avoid injuries.
  3.)  To protect the environment.
  4.)  To minimize property damage.

Baker Commodities maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM an

d RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes due to the renovation of the facility.

In case of an ammonia emergency, Baker Commodities plans to evacuate all employees in the facility and alert the local emergency responders (fire department).  Baker Commodities plans to coordinate emergency response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazard Analysis, Seismic Assessment, and Hazard Assessment (Off-Site Consequence Analysis) provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the Baker Commodities facility located at 4100 Bandini Avenue, Vernon, California. 

R01:   Obtain a hand held ammonia detector to determine ammonia concentration in engine room.

R02:    Coordinate emergency response activities with the local emergency responders (i.e., fire department) on a periodic and ongoing basis to determine fire department requirements, and to communicate operator's abilities to the fire department. 

R03:    Either test water pH in diffusion tank periodically or install ammonia detector at the top of diffusion tank.  Include in Mechanical Integrity program.

R04:    Do not store flammable materials such as pallets or extra oil drums in engine room.

R05:   Implement a maintenance program to replace/reseat relief valves every five years (as per industry standard).  Automatically replace any relief valves that unseat.  Include in Mechanical Integrity program.

R06:   Conduct annual visual inspections of vessels, paint and repair any signs of corrosion as necessary.  Include in Mechanical Integrity program.

R07:    Reassess if system should require manual restart after power outage.

R08:   Implement and document maintenance procedures per IIAR Bulletin 110 as well as establish a procedure to have operators complete a daily walkthrough of refrigeration equipment and daily log sheet.  Include in Mechanical Integrity program.

R09:   Conduct monthly testing of eye wash stations an

d showers.  Include in Mechanical Integrity program.

R10:   Establish a procedure to discuss pipe opening procedure prior to beginning work.  Also, work in pairs when carrying out this type of work.    

R11:   Conduct an ammonia awareness training program that includes informing all employees of the following: 1) the presence of and the hazards associated with ammonia at the facility, 2) how to recognize the odor, 3) what to do if they observe an ammonia leak, 4) where to go when they are told to evacuate.  

R12:   Conduct additional training for those employees who use safety equipment.

R13:   If ammonia is released into the sewer, inform proper authorities.  

R14:   On an annual basis, verify that the level shown by the computer can be verified by the level column reading.  Also, test the high and low level alarms/switches annually.  Include in Mechanical Integrity program.

R15:   Document training of new employees on draining oil by having trainer and trainee certify that training has occurred and was understood.

R16:    Annually inspect insulation to ensure it has no tears to ensure proper vapor seal.  Repair any damaged insulation.  Include in Mechanical Integrity program.

R17:   Ensure that all evaporator coils are periodically maintained by cleaning the pans and coils per IIAR Bulletin 110 Guidelines (include criteria in maintenance program).  Include in Mechanical Integrity program.

R18:   Prior to working on evaporator valves, maintenance operators should inform someone where they will be working and how long they will be on the roof.    

R19:   To minimize accidents, identify potential problem areas in the layout of evaporators and piping with respect to  shelving in dock area.

R20:    Include in the written maintenance program at least an annual test to verify compressor shut down safeties are functioning properly.  Include in Mechanical Integrity program.
